captions.text:
As your leader...
[ fatale translating
in japanese ]

...I encourage you
from time to time,

And always
in a respectful manner,

A particular plan of action
I've decided is the wisest,
But allow me to convince you.

And I promise you,
right here and now,
No subject will ever be taboo.

Except, of course, the subject
that was just under discussion.

For bringing up either
my chinese or american heritage

Now, if any of you
sons of bitches

Got anything else to say,
now is the fucking time!

title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (6/12) Movie CLIP - Tanaka Loses His Head (2003) HD

comments.author: Kareem “Car008” James

comments.text:
It's an Anime / Mange trope of how trying to sound serious is actually 
speaking English. Like how in American TV show and stereo types, if you 
want to sound smart or clever, speak in a British accent. If you want to be 
funny speak in a Hindi.
comments.author: steven shar

comments.text:
Several reasons.  Sean Clark's point, the fact that English would 
invariably be the second language to the rest of the crime council (show of 
dominance), the fact that English is mainly the business language in Japan 
(underscoring the seriousness of the policy outline), and also the 
possibility that she's talking to the audience.  This scene, more than the 
anime sequence that preceded it, draws for us in gory detail exactly who 
the Bride is dealing with when she decides "I'm going to kill O-Ren Ishii." 
 She wants people to pay attention to her, not some disembodied lines of 
text on the bottom of the screen.

comments.author: Zach Martin

comments.text:
Anybody notice a movie error in this? When she cuts off tanakas head, watch 
her grip on her sword, then when she starts to turn back to the other 
bosses (before splatting blood on that guy's face) her hand grip on the 
sword is facing the other way...﻿
comments.author: Michael Peralta

comments.text:
The director spoke of this... during shooting the unplanned happened when 
she tried to sheath the sword with a reverse grip... it looked awkward and 
distracted from the scene hence the switch.
comments.author: Eloel

comments.text:
Yes I did notice and the reasons for that are to make her look more bad ass 
on both scenes. I think Tarantino wanted to capture a close up shot 
of the blood spurting out of the neck, Liu's face and the sword in hand. 
Problem is you can't really pull the kind of shot if the blade is out to 
the side which it would be if you she were holding it properly rather than 
behind her when she used the reverse grip way. Second shot, Tarantino 
wanted her to shake the blood off her blade but you can't practically do 
when you hold the katana in the reverse grip.
